inhibition at 50 μg/mL concentration. d Not determined. Conclusions Phytochemical investigation of CH 2 2 2 2 Mitrephora tomentosa 1 5 1 3 N 4 5 6 11 12 2 6 1 Experimental Section General Experimental Procedures Optical rotations were
determined using a Jasco P-102 digital polarimeter (JASCO Corporation,
Tokyo, Japan) at the D-line of the sodium lamp at 589 nm. UV–visible
spectra were obtained from a Shimadzu UV-1700 PharmaSpec Spectrometer.
Electronic circular dichroism (ECD) spectra of the isolated compounds
were obtained on a JASCO J-815 CD spectropolarimeter, employing a
1 mm quartz cell at room temperature. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR)
spectra were measured using a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrometer
equipped with a universal attenuated total reflectance (UATR) accessory
(PerkinElmer, Waltham, USA). The nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR)
spectra were acquired in CDCl 3 d 6 1 13 1 13 254 p All commercial grade solvents, including n 2 2 Plant Material The Mitrephora tomentosa Extraction and Isolation The air-dried bark of M. tomentosa 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 2 The crude CH 2 2 2 2 2 2 1 8 2 15 14 3 2 2 3.1 3.6 3.6 18 4 2 2 4.1 4.12 4.4 2 2 9 4.4 2 2 4.4.1 4.4.12 4.4.1 4.4.3 4.4.5 4.4.8 3 2 1 10 4.9 17 5 2 2 1 7 2 2 7.1 7.4 7.1 19 7.2 2 2 16 7.3 12 Similarly, the crude CH 2 2 2 2 1 4 1 2 2 3 2 1 3 2 2 3.1 3.6 3.3 3.3.1 3.3.5 3.3.2 3.3.2.1 3.3.2.7 3.3.2.1 2 2 3.3.2.1.1 3.3.2.1.3 3.3.2.1.2 2 2 7 6 3.3.2.3 8 3.3.2.4 2 2 5 3.3.2.6 2 2 4 3.3.2.7 13 3.3.4 2 2 3.3.4.1 3.3.4.3 3.3.4.2 2 2 11 Mitrephorine A ( 1 light yellow powder;

UV (CH 2 2 max max –1 1 13 Table 19 14 5 m z + 19 14 5 X-ray Crystal Structure Analysis of Compound 1 Single crystals of compound 1 T  2 3 U iso U eq The crystallographic data are available free of charge through https://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/structures/ 2422525 1 Tables S5–S7 Crystallization of compound 1 37 28 2 6 3 P 1 n a b c V 3 Z D c –3 –1 F 000 max R int R 1 wR 2 R I I F 2 max –3 Methodology for ECD Analysis A conformational search
was conducted using Spartan’20 software with the MMFF94 molecular
mechanics mode, considering conformers within an energy window of
5 kcal/mol. All DFT calculations were carried out using Gaussian
16  S R 1 R 5   R S 1 S 5 Supporting Information Cell Lines and Culture Conditions A diverse panel of
10 human cancer cell lines representing various tissue origins and
subtypes [adherent cultures of human cholangiocarcinoma (HuCCA-1),
lung (A549), cervical carcinoma (HeLa), hormone-dependent breast (T-47D),
hepatocellular carcinoma (HepG2), hormone-independent breast (MDA-MB-231),
liver (S102), and multidrug-resistant lung (H69AR) cancers] and one
normal embryonic lung fibroblast (MRC-5) cell line were used. Suspension
cultures of human promyeloblast (HL-60) and T lymphoblast (MOLT-3)
were also included. Cell lines were either purchased from the American
Type Culture Collection (ATCC) or received as gifts from collaborating
laboratories. Adherent cells were cultured in Dulbecco’s Modified
Eagle Medium (DMEM), Ham’s F-12, or RPMI-1640 medium, and suspension
cells were cultured in RPMI-1640 medium; all media were supplemented
with 10–20% fetal bovine serum and appropriate additives such
as l 2 Cytotoxicity Assays Test compounds and positive controls
(doxorubicin, etoposide, and doxorubicin hydrochloride) were prepared
as 10 mg/mL stock solutions in DMSO and diluted with the corresponding
culture medium prior to use. Cells were seeded in 96-well plates at
5,000–20,000 cells per well depending on growth rates and allowed
to attach or equilibrate. After 48 h treatment, cell viability was
assessed using the MTT assay (3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium
bromide) for adherent cells H 50 Supplementary Material This research was supported by the Thailand Science
Research and Innovation program (TSRI), Chulabhorn Research Institute
(Grant No. 50250/4772841) and the Center of Excellence on Environmental
Health and Toxicology (EHT), Ministry of Higher Education, Science,
Research and Innovation (MHESI), Office of the Permanent Secretary
(OPS). The authors thank Theerawat Thananthaisong for the plant material
identification, the graphical abstract photo of M. tomentosa The NMR experimental
